content.description: Ascend the obvious crack on the right side of a column to a small roof then work up body position dependent holds on a beautiful wavy column, past a key full-paper-towel-roll sized block that may come loose but seemed solid for me, to an excellent clipping position for the anchor.
content.protection: chain permadraws, cold shunts at the anchor
content.location: From the leftmost side of the crag, second route in

content.description: Talus Dancer starts out on a massive undercling before moving to cool compression climbing up a column. The moves up the column get progressively trickier until the 4th/5th bolt (crux). Get a good rest before pulling over the roof on massive jugs and traversing back left to the anchor.
content.protection: 7 bolts to cold shuts, all but the first have permadraws
content.location: On the left side of the wall, locate the obvious crack that marks the start of Talus Dweller. This routes starts about 8 ft to the right. When the two sets of bolts diverge, take the right fork. (TH3 shares a start and finish with this route, but breaks off left in the middle.)

content.description: This route reminds me of McDevitt Route aka the 11c warmup at Jailhouse. Sustained climbing with not many rests. At the anchors about 40-50 feet up you can continue leftward into Divine for the extension, which entails some fun endurance climbing that doesn't change the grade.
content.location: Divine is to the left and Bicipital Groove is to the right. Starts on a big sheared-off column that looks like a cut-off tree trunk.

content.description:
The classic steep climb at Columns. Probably overhangs 60 ft but only gains 25 ft in elevation.

Pull a few easier moves to get off the ground and clip the first two bolts before getting into a sit-down rest. Collect your thoughts then move horizontally using lots of kneebars and roof climbing trickery to get to a good rest around the 6th bolt. Clip the 7th draw (black) then fire a bouldery crux before pulling on a few more jugs to reach the chains. Super classic.
content.protection: 8 fixed draws to a cold shut
content.location: There are 3 routes that start at the very right side of the main cave at Columns. The leftmost of these is Spin Doctor (the other two are Hey Ladies and Megatron). Identify it by 5 chain draws, followed by two cable draws (6th is red, 7th is black).

content.description:
Finesse up the crack/column for 3 bolts to a big jug and reach high to clip the 4th bolt. Instead of breaking right as for Divine Microphone (aka the Warm up), continue straight up on underclings and sidepulls for another 4 bolts, trending right then breaking back left just before the anchor.

Note: At the 8th bolt, you'll see a pair of mussy hooks on the left (anchor for Blow of Death) and a lone bolt without a permadraw on the right (the original finish for Divine). Ignore both of those and continue straight up for another 8 ft, heading towards a large undercling flake just below the anchor.
content.protection: 8 bolts, usually all but the first one has fixed chains
content.location: On the lower wall, look for two detatched 4 ft tall columns sticking up out of the talus. Mr. Microphone starts just to the right of the left of the two columns.

content.description:
Climb up flakes and jugs for a couple of clips until the route takes a hard left. If you are tall enough, lean out and clip the draw out to the left and commit to the crux section involving cross-through moves, side-pulls, and slopers; this section is very nice and finishes with a move back up and right to well deserved rest. Finish by climbing straight up on easier, but engaging climbing.

Good rock, good movement, and fun climbing.
content.location: The furthest route on the right side of the lower tier routes (Behemoth is the last route on the right of the lower tier before the upper cave).

climbs.name: Hey Ladies
climbs.fa: Likely either John Scott and Troy Corliss or Tom Hebert

content.description: The climbing on this route utilizes many knee bars, scums, and heal hooks to traverse 8 bolts of upside down mostly horizontal climbing; most climbers will want a knee pad or two. Have a quick hand at the belay on this one because you are never far from the ground and a blown knee scum while clipping will put you close to the dirt (talus mostly).
content.location: The second to the last route on the far right end of the main cave.

climbs.name: Divine Microphone (aka the Warm-up)
climbs.fa: Officially Brian Carkeet and Donnie Anderson mid-2000s, but quite possibly climbed earlier

content.description:
Begin by climbing up a shallow groove between two columns using face holds and finger locks. Clip the fourth bolt and merge onto the next route to the right. Continue upwards on fun climbing with relatively large holds with short harder sections in between good rests. Quite a fun route.

This route is really a combination of two different 5.12 routes, but since it is the most common warm-up for the area, I have entered it.
content.location: Begin on the the sixth route from the left (Mr. Microphone) of the lower tier routes. Keep in mind that although this route starts on the sixth route from the left, it actually starts on the fifth bolt line from the left owing to the fact that two of the routes to the left begin with a shared start. At the fourth bolt, merge onto the next route to the right (Divine).

climbs.name: Divine
climbs.fa: Likely either John Scott and Troy Corliss or Tom Hebert

content.description: Begin with easy climbing past the first two bolts to a sheared off column that forms a mini roof and marks the start of the crux. Clip the third draw and pull through the crux using gastons and sidepulls. It is a bit of a distance to the fourth clip, but by the time you are up a ways from the third clip, you are on much easier climbing and you should have no problem. At this point, climb up and slightly left before heading up and right for the final long section of fun 5.10/5.11 climbing.
content.protection: Usually all fixed draws except for bolts one, two, and four. Lower off.
content.location: Immediately to the right of Mr. Microphone (which is also the start of the Warmup route) are two routes that start right next to each other and begin on two separate short, sheared off columns; Divine is the left route of these two routes.

content.description: Begin by climbing up easy, vertical flakes and jugs to the beginning of the steep roof. Next, follow the obvious line of fixed draws out the horizontal roof for maybe 30 feet. The roof section involves traversing huge jugs, but owing to the steep nature of the roof (you actually climb slightly downwards towards the end of the roof), this section is fairly pumpy. At the end of the roof, pull the lip and clip the anchors that are slightly up and left.
content.protection: 10 fixed draws to a huge hook anchor.
content.location: Start in the center of the cave (maybe the 4th route from the right of the main cave). See the beta photo for the location, but it should be kind of obvious because it is the route in the way back of the cave with chalked up flake/jugs for starting holds.

content.description:
This route is long and pumpy, engaging moves the whole way and a heart-breaking finish.

Climb up the column on decent holds requiring very sequential movement. At the top of the column, grab a decent rest on a large undercling by the fifth bolt. From here, pull the small roof and pass two more bolts to a good rest. After clipping the eighth bolt, make a small traverse right, clip the last (9th) draw and save some energy for the final crack up to the chains.
content.location: Eight feet left of Divine and ten feet right of the obvious crack that marks the start of Talus Dweller.

content.description: Start in a corner immediately right of Bicipital Groove. Climb up the corner for a few feet, clip the first bolt and then move right. The hanging dagger above the belay looks scary, though it's solid and easy to avoid. Continue moving up and right through very 3-dimensional climbing to a good rest below the roof. Traverse right and dyno out the roof to a massive jug. Clip here, then hang on for two more bolts of pumpy climbing before the angle eases up right below the chains.
content.location: To the right of the main warm-up area in the lower cave, look for a large hanging dagger (or tooth). Bicipital Groove goes left of this and Blade Runner goes right.

content.description: Make a few easy moves to get off the ground, then into a somewhat bouldery sequence on underclings for a few feet. Move right to a huge undercling block then up to a hidden jug. From here, follow good holds up and left to a good no-hands rest at 1/2 height. After the rest, the climbing eases to 5.10-5.11 for another 50ish ft to the chains below a small conifer.
content.location: On the wall to the left of the main cave, this is the fourth route from the right. It's 8-10 ft right of Sugar Brown and 12-15 ft right of Mr. Microphone/Divine Microphone. Look for several large underclings about 10 ft up that look like huge hanging teeth.

content.description: Rad pitch on the left side of the cave. First route to the right of la dentista.
content.location: The most left line of the cave (right of la dentista). Left of 13c.
